It's also a bug against podman that you can't add more networks if there are no networks defined or one of them is broken

3rd party integrations may rely on the net being there. That being said, we run into issues ourselves because this role is shared with CI functions.  IMHO we shouldn't intentionally break software on installation.

I guess the problem is we don't know. Removing heat, does that mean removing tripleo-heat-templates, or does it mean processing them with something else? AFAIK there is no spec or design discussion openly available, so who knows ... Removing THT means switching the entire user interface. IMO that would be not good, 3rd party integrations would suffer etc.

My change also simplifies the heat based nic configs, if you insist on keeping this in ansible I can update the patch to not concatenate the groupvars value. But we should do the work setting the ansible fact so that the user facing ansible templates are kept as simple as possible.

I'm not blocking your patch, just saying that it does not align with the long term strategy of everything ansible. Unless we go the heat as a library way, THT won't have any significance. Network resource management had been the least problem area for heat, but we want to get rid of it, isn't it ? And hence all what we're doing atm.

My only point is if we want everything in ansible then let's not add all these manipulations that use yaql and heat intrinsic functions.

Though I completely agree that it would make the jinja templates simpler.

AFAIU the assumption is there would be no replacement for heat as everything would be ansibilized;) So all these data manipulations would be in ansible unless it's done by the cli tool you're proposing. So yeah we can move these to some additional set_fact tasks in the role if we want.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_hieradata/.message:
In my env where I tested this change I found that we should explicitly set this variable because in a standard deployment it's not evaluated and haproxy conf rely on controller_virtual_vip.

internal_ip     => hiera('ceph_dashboard_vip', $controller_virtual_ip)

To check this I run 'hiera -c /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml ceph_dashboard_vip' and it resulted to "nil", instead, controller_virtual_ip contained the right value.
So my idea was basically make sure that this variable is always set (through this 'else' statement) and then get it via [1].


[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/755004/8/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_ceph_work_dir/tasks/prepare.yml@49

Please prefer to use the official corresponding patch:

```
From 41d43e1ab71f2270341c9c29ecbae7eec4465030 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Sébastien Boyron <sboyron@redhat.com>
Date: Thu, 08 Oct 2020 16:19:39 +0200
Subject: [PATCH] Add catch for OSError and KeyError (PEP	3151)

During RPM packaging SUSE CI where raising KeyError and
OSError [0].

[0] https://review.opendev.org/755159

Change-Id: I47e25d3c70183e7617e42ac83a55f3d6e4f7a70f
---

diff --git a/tripleoclient/utils.py b/tripleoclient/utils.py
index 677e2bf..6955d4a 100644
--- a/tripleoclient/utils.py
+++ b/tripleoclient/utils.py
@@ -592,7 +592,7 @@
     get_uid = int(os.getenv('SUDO_UID', os.getuid()))
     try:
         user_pwd = pwd.getpwuid(get_uid)
-    except TypeError:
+    except (KeyError, TypeError):
         home = constants.CLOUD_HOME_DIR
     else:
         home = user_pwd.pw_dir
diff --git a/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_netenv_validate.py b/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_netenv_validate.py
index cd06acf..15f1b03 100644
--- a/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_netenv_validate.py
+++ b/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_netenv_validate.py
@@ -163,7 +163,7 @@
         try:
             with open(path, 'r') as nic_file:
                 nic_data = yaml.safe_load(nic_file)
-        except IOError:
+        except (IOError, OSError):
             self.log.error(
                 'The resource "%s" reference file does not exist: "%s"',
                 resource, path)
```

nit: following
This seems confusing... the "mtce" user is unable to access the "mtce" repo?

We would like to use an existing service user so that the credentials did not change and the user cannot be deleted. Mtce seems suitable since it fits that criteria.

If you want a separate user created to act as the public registry user, we would need to add that as a service user. On top of that, we currently cannot patch the creation of a new user and the mechanism for adding a new keystone user during upgrade was never fixed to my knowledge. If we take this approach, we would at the very minimum need to wait until the next release in order to add the new keystone user.
This feels like a hack. If we were to do this properly, what would be the solution? Creating a new user? If so, do we have plans to migrate to a proper solution in a future release?

We want to treat the "mtce" user as a public user for the system, and close off the "mtce" repo to the user.

If we leave the mtce repo open to the mtce user, putting the mtce user's credentials in the containerd config would allow deployment of images from the mtce repo through kubernetes without pull secrets.

we chose to use an existing user (mtce) instead of creating a new one in this case to avoid upgrade and patching complications.
I'm pretty sure this is helpful, or at least --versions w/o --json was previously NOT helpful

swiftclient/service.py.message: it's not obvious to me that "delete all the current versions in a container" should be unexpressable at this level.

I guess the question is, what do users want to have happen when running `swift delete --all`? I was thinking they wanted to clean up their account entirely and stop getting billed for bytes stored. It seemed (to me) like a weird break from prior behavior that a delete --all would leave containers behind and drop a bunch of 409s if you had containers with versioning enabled.

Maybe `swift delete --all --versions` is better/the new way to go? I suppose the main smell for me was the 409s, and I'm not even fully addressing that. We should have enough information in our heads to (mostly) avoid it -- maybe I'll just look at doing *that*, and maybe even give a hint about --versions if the user actually wanted to delete all data.

Just to add about alpine. There are 2 benefits: due to the fact that the image is more lightweight - there is less number of packages and the probability of CVE is lower than for std ubuntu images. Alpine base image is always up-to-date. That means that from the security perspective it will be 'at least' not worse than ubuntu. In practice it will most likely be better.
Since I'm working with image delivery I see the trend that lots of people prefer 'alpine-based' images because of benefits with security

I think this could be used in several conditions :

1. during dev on a spec: so a --dev option or a default comportement checking local not-yet committed changes to establish the list of .spec to check could be a good option; if no local modif, check the files modified by the latest commit. 

2. For cleaning purpose: In this case a --all option should be good to check all the .spec of the repo and generate a global report (in a first time or performing the actions in a second time)

3. Regarding the maturity it can be maybe used as pre-commit script: in this case local changes have to be checked. 

4. Maybe one day it could be used as a CI check, in this case, specs modified by latest commit should be the target.

- treat all spec files if --all/-a is passed
- checking local change to establish the list of specs
- having a look on latest commit
- if latest commit does not touch any .spec.j2 file, treat nothing.

Agreed

Since you did not removed "Requires:" from reqs, you are searching it into the spec file.
My feeling is that this is not really a good idea.
Ah yes good point

doing this grep will return true if the spec match el even if it is part of a word. you do not ensure matching the right requirements (eg: grep tripleo will return true even if there is only python-tripleoclient required)
You should perform a :

grep -i "\<${el}\>" ${spec}

This will force checking the word $el.
Since in your example you are using oslo.privsep, it you want to be precise you should replace the '.' which is matching all char by a \. to force checking a dot.
so maybe a : 

grep -i "\<${el/./\\\.}\>" ${spec}}

Indeed you should even perform this :

grep -i "^[[:space:]]*Requirements:[[:space:]]*\<${el/./\\\.}\>" $spec

to ensure it is a Requirements spec and not a BuildRequirement or a comment.

You may can replace some [[:space:]] from the regex if we have some linting on it to simplify the readability of it in the future. I did not really check what is really checked on linting on this part.

This can be peformed with BuilRequirements as well of course.

No you are wrong, I only want to capture files related to one commit (either specified by the given sha or the HEAD of the current branch if no sha is given).

My goal is not to parse all our files or all our commits, my goal is only to analyze delta on a specific commit to allow us to:
1. analyze changes landed by the last commit (head)
    1.a on CI
    1.b with pre-commit
    1.c locally by calling this script without params
2. analyze unstagged changes to help us during versions updates

So normally we don't have scenario where a merge commit will be analyzed except if you pass a related sha to the tool but in this case it wouldn't loop over files, in other words in this scenario nothing will happen.

On CI we need to pass the sha by using zuul.

Locally we haven't to pass something, if unstagged changes exist it will analyze them, else it will analyze the last commit, no matter if this last commit is a merge commit or not.

This is useless; your sed command already doing it (better) in the first part of the regex : 
/ is for searching a pattern, next operation will be done only on this line .

  /set[[:space:]]*upstream_version/

this is looking for the line set with some spaces or tab then upstream_version keyword. 

Indeed while reviewving it, I can propose to use : 

  /^[[:space:]]*set[[:space:]]*upstream_version/

instead to ensure you are not using a commented ligne.

Then you removed the -n and p from my latest proposition. 
-n will change sed to output nothing
p command will print only the treated line
=> it will so act like a grep.

Global command is so : 

sed -n "/^[[:space:]]*set[[:space:]]*upstream_version/s/.*'\([^']*\)'.*/\1/" ${file}

nit: This code is duplicated. You may extract it as a common method in NimbleBaseVolumeDriver.

This looks like it would be an issue. If a volume is multiattach, it looks like you won't remove anything until all attachments are removed. So if you have a volume exposed to two different hosts, and the operator removes the attachment from one of the hosts, this will still keep the volume exposed to both until later when it is also removed from the other host.

Worse, if it is a long running environment and the volume is added and removed from various hosts over time, eventually it will be exposed to several hosts when in reality it is only being used by one host.

this doesn't seem right.

mtce/src/scripts/crashDumpMgr.message: Would it be better to get these off the rootfs right away? I thought we were going to tar these up directly to /var/log/crash or something and do the rotation there.
There was talk about that but if I put them in /var/log then they will be collected by standard collect.
It should be a minor change to collect to ignore the specific directory. Otherwise, the code you have here is in danger of filling up the root fs.
Then collect has to be patched back as well.

Should use $() rather than the backticks.
Also, the () inside the backticks is unnecessary, as it's already in a subprocess.

That said, why not just do "for entry in ${CRASH_DIR}/*"?
Yes, I know, I opted for option 1 $(). Its done. It just seemed to grow so what I had with backticks changed to $() was fine.

I'll use $() since the suggested 
'for entry in ${CRASH_DIR}/*' includes the CRASH_DIR in the entry and I don't want that.
I saw the benefit (simplification) you were suggesting.
You mean it includes the pathname? That would normally be handled by doing a basename to get just the root name. ie. $(basename ${entry})

I think you can achieve the same without the subprocess, using the -C option:
tar -cf ${OTHER_BUNDLE} -C ${CRASH_DIR} ${entry}
I assume the tar operation is limited to a single core. Is there any concern about cpu (or disk) usage at init time? Should we be nicing this operation? Maybe Jim or Jim could comment?
Discussed with SME's and made suggested changes.

mtce/src/scripts/crashdump.logrotate.message: Is this setting globals that impact other logrotate files, or is it restricted to this config? Why not just set these in each file config?

We may want to have more rotates for the vmcore.tar in the future when/if crash dumps are moved to its own filesystem   so I'd like to keep them separate.

If you feel strongly please make additional comment.

If this is the same for both, I think you could merge these configs into one, such as:

/var/crash/vmcore.tar
/var/crash/vmcore_first.tar
{
  size 1K
  rotate 1
  nodateext
  start 1
  missingok
  notifempty
  compress
  postrotate
    rm -f $1
  endscript
}
